So, you know, one of her key books is The Left Hand of Darkness, and she's very interested in exploring kind of alternate universes.
What does it mean when you encounter someone who can change gender at different points in their life?
What would that do to your whole kind of system of belief and thought? It completely throws the narrator in quite interesting ways.
So she's very interested in the anthropology of that sort of stuff. And she's also quite early on.
I mean, the understanding of ecology and the damage being done to the ecologies of fragile ecologies of the Earth was beginning to emerge in the 1960s.
This is all quite very early kind of stuff. But she was very interested in that.
So maybe native cultures that you encounter have a different relationship to nature. It's not seen as a resource to be used and consumed, but that you live with in totally different ways.
And that has been hugely influential, too. So she's a kind of very, again, soft science fiction, liberal end, interested in intellectual, social ideas, sociology and anthropology.
The kind of stuff that, say, Asimov or Heinlein are less interested in, although they have many things to say about it.
Her focus is not on hard technology necessarily, but on these ideas of encounter, I think. So she's crucial.
Another figure is Saniswap Lem, who is Polish, I believe. What were his concerns and ideas?
And what do they tell us about that point, I suppose, in European and international history?
Yeah, it's so important to and I hope we can say more about this towards the end.
But it's so important to have a kind of international or multinational perspective for science fiction.
So we're beginning to understand that although we've had this endless argument about is HG Wells the father of science fiction?
Actually, there are lots of traditions that are emerging around about the same time in many different kind of nations.
And so there is a kind of tradition in Russian writing and Soviet Union writing, which of course is very interested in utopia.
In fact, the Bolsheviks who drove the revolution wrote science fiction.
They wrote utopian kind of science fiction, some of them quite explicitly.
And, you know, we're very interested in the politics of that, of projecting futures.
They were very interested in futurism, those sorts of ideas.
By the time you get someone like Stanislav Lem, who is writing in what was then a satellite communist state.
So part of the part of the whole Soviet Union alliance in the East during the Cold War.
He's got a slightly different relationship to science fiction.
So the virtue of it is that it can be allegorical.
That is, you can write about the state that you're in without directly criticising the state, because as soon as you do, your work gets suppressed.
So science fiction becomes a very kind of powerful device or a genre in which you can displace your criticism and begin to kind of target some concerns.
So I think he's important for that. He's very interested in science and technology, but also has this sort of softer edge.
So if you read Solaris, which has been filmed twice, both times brilliantly, but very differently.
That's about a bunch of scientists who are sent to a planet to try and communicate with what seems to be a planetary consciousness.
And it's communicating in a completely different way from from language.
It kind of extracts your worst memory from your mind and kind of beams it back at you.
And is there any possibility of communicating with this absolute other?
So that's a really interesting, crucial kind of story.
And there are many figures like Lem who kind of right on the edge of censorship and being suppressed by by Communist Party state who don't like this stuff.
They don't they don't want this kind of material. They want happy tractor driver kind of realist material.
So they're kind of treated with suspicion on the edge of this.
And it makes their work really intriguing. And you have to interpret quite hard what it is that they might be getting at.
So that's true also of say this Drogatsky brothers who wrote Roadside Picnic, which became Stalker, a film by Tarkovsky.
And it's a very influential story because it's about alien technology that no one understands that you sort of pick up and it either does wondrous things to you or it kills you or it mutates you.
And no one quite understands what it is. But that was a book that was suppressed as somehow in some way critical.
We're not sure how, but we would like to ban and censor this anyway.
So that sense of how you might use science fiction again in a sort of political context as a sort of way of displacing criticism is very important.
Spaghetti Tree on Twitter wants to know about the impacts of the early Cold War in that transitional period where science began to truly influence literature.
Is there something about the Cold War that we can say more generally about science fiction and history?
Yeah, that is a really good question. And I do think, you know, so I've written a history of science fiction, which I hinge around 1945 because I think 1945 is an absolutely crucial moment.
That's when we get the atom bomb being used. That is the first super weapon that's been imagined for so many decades by science fiction actually realised.
HG Wells predicted an atom bomb in 1914 and he thought it would emerge around about 1945.
So that's kind of a fairly amazing kind of sense of what they were understanding about, you know, the projection into the future.
You can release this extraordinary energy. But what that of course produced was these absolutely implacably opposed blocks between West and East, the Soviet Union and its communist allies.
Versus America and its capitalist allies. And you get lots of science fiction, which is either utterly dystopian.
So imagining nuclear meltdowns of various kinds or survival of nuclear catastrophe in various kinds of ways.
But you also get a sort of drive to try and think beyond these political divisions.
That's actually what Arthur C. Clarke's most transcendent work is about, is he's always saying we need to leave behind human division and these political kind of shifts.
And it's only science, it's only space travel moving outwards that can allow us to transcend this, which is why his visions are so sort of ecstatic.
You know, the end of 2001, whatever the hell that means, is a sort of vision of transcendence of these kinds of political moments.
So the Cold War is really, really very important. And you get someone like Robert Heinen again, who works out the kind of logic of mutually assured destruction.
That is, you know, we've got a bomb. If you set yours off, we'll set ours off. Everyone, everything ends.
So it's a kind of, you know, a stalemate. He works out that logic in the middle of the Second World War.
You know, that's a sense of right before all the politicians have got there.
An American writer like Judith Merrill takes a very different view of this.
So, you know, what's the effect of this on mothers, on motherhood? What if you produce your mutant children? What's going to happen about that?
Octavia Butler, another really important writer emerging in the 1970s, is sort of saying that humanity is kind of doomed with this kind of violence and constant drive to domination.
So we actually need to actively embrace the alien other and become something else, move beyond our division.
And that is also, I mean, hers is driven by a question around race.
She was one of the earliest black women science fiction writers. But it's also clearly a Cold War logic as well of let's just move beyond this kind of division.

And you get really weird things happening so that in 1980s, some some listeners might remember that Ronald Reagan had this whole project called Star Wars, which was, you know, to kind of put a defence system in space.
That was written for him by a group of science fiction writers.
Robert Heinlein, Greg Bear were heavily involved in that. They wrote a report out of their science fiction, which then became government policy.
You know, it's extraordinary the influence that those science fiction writers had.
They were all very politically motivated to help the Republican Party and to, in a sense, extend the Cold War into space itself.
And so, you know, this vision perhaps didn't work because it was science fiction. But nevertheless, it got billions of dollars. It's amazing.
That leads nicely, actually, talking about the ideas in which science fiction has influenced reality.

N.P. Ryan on Twitter asks, Is it right to say that Churchill's initial fear that Londoners wouldn't come back out of underground stations if allowed to shelter from bombs in them came from the time machine, the H.G. Wells story?
Do you know whether that's true or not?
I can't answer whether it's specifically true or not.
But I think there is that that was certainly the view was that if people were allowed to go into the underground system, then they would never come out.
And the kind of the economy would sort of collapse. So there was a genuine kind of fear about that.
There is a sort of imagination of science fiction, which is kind of bubbling around, which has these visions of underground living, which become even stronger in the Cold War.

So bunker living and this idea of we all ending up in bunkers. There's a great novel by Philip K. Dick, the 1950s American writer, called The Penultimate Truth, which is where humanity has basically been for decades living in bunkers underground,
watching news feeds of robots fighting a war on the surface. And they discover that the robots are just simply making films and that there has been no war for decades.
And they've all been tricked into this kind of system by artificial intelligences.
So, you know, there is a sense of a of a bunker kind of imagination to science fiction.
So maybe Churchill was picking up on that. He did read absolutely everything.
We should return to the idea that you mentioned earlier about other traditions or other voices that haven't been given, perhaps the recognition that they might otherwise deserve.
Who should we champion? Who should we highlight that we haven't already talked about in this conversation?
Yeah. So, I mean, I think there are many. It's a golden age right now. It's a golden age of science fiction.
Really, there's so much extraordinary work. But I think what's extraordinary about it is this explosion across the whole globe.
So it's now impossible for someone like me to sit here and say, I've read everything in science fiction.
You might have been able to do that maybe in 1950 and it's becoming very difficult.
But now it's simply impossible. And we need kind of experts. There's a whole Indian kind of science fiction world.
There's a whole African science fiction, lots of different kind of countries producing lots of different kinds of work.
I've just been reading The Old Drift by Namwali Serpal, which won the best science fiction novel, Arthur C. Clarke Award in 2020.
And that's set in Zambia. And you just think, is this a science fiction novel? And it slowly, carefully does take you into a science fictional world in a really clever, ingenious kind of way.
And it feels very significant, vital, important kind of work that's being done.
There's a thing called Gulf Futurism, which is a kind of science fiction that's emerging from the Middle East.
So Frankenstein in Baghdad, amazing book by Ahmed Sadawi, which reimagines the monster in the middle of the Iraq war.
This is a monster put together from the body parts of people who've been blown up in the explosive, in explosions.
And it kind of enacts the revenge of all the people who've been killed. It feels like a completely new, brilliant world of invention.

So there's loads of stuff that's going on. And if people are able to get to London in October, there is a whole massive exhibition called Science Fiction at the Science Museum, which is trying to explore these ideas.
I was involved in the development of that over the last five years, and they've been really committed to this idea of a global vision.
So there's a quick way of doing that. It's going to be a great exhibition.
Thank you so much. I wanted to end with just a few quick questions. We've had LDOP Exeter asks, what sci fi tropes have we achieved?
And they suggest sliding doors, data pads, medical scans. And what have we missed? Hoverboard, Soylent Green. I mean, some of them I'd argue it's a good thing we've missed.
Is there something we can say about the shape that history has taken compared to the shape that science fiction offered? Or is that too impossible?
Yeah, I mean, I think it's a really good question. It's a perennial question as well. So should you measure science fiction by, you know, what it accurately predicts?

And there is a there's a there's a famous book and phrase which is, you know, where's my jet board dude or whatever it was called, you know, that that sense of where's my where is all of this promise of this technology?
It hasn't arrived. So these but they're sometimes called retro futures. This idea that, you know, back in the 50s, everything we didn't need food anymore. We just have a pill and it would be great.
Or there'd be no work. You know, labor would be kind of ended and we'd all just lie around in hammocks and order around robots.
And that hasn't happened. But on the other hand, I think it's much more interesting to look at how certain kind of imagination and explorations of technology have slowly kind of arrived.
So many people say that the the mobile phone in America has this very different flip kind of device, doesn't it?
So you kind of often open it out. And that's all because of Star Trek. So, you know, it needed to be like the communicators in in Star Trek.
If you read Arthur C. Clarke on the future of computing in the 1960s, so he'd already predicted satellites.
And then he said, well, I think we're going to basically in the future have a handheld kind of device, a computer where you can watch television.
You can communicate with your friends. It would be, you know, by by vision and sound.
You wouldn't need to worry about telephones anymore. And he's describing and also describing the shape when you see him on TV in the 60s of an iPad.
And it's kind of fairly extraordinary that you can do that. People sometimes go to the kind of work of, say, James Cameron, a filmmaker, director who did Avatar,
but also Steven Spielberg, who in his science fictions kind of he hires futurologists in order to try and just kind of tilt things slightly into the future.
So, you know, their films are predicting, well, they create new technology. That's why James Cameron takes so long to produce a film is he has to invent a camera to film it.
But in Spielberg's case, you know, iris recognition, all that sort of stuff is going on in his kind of films.
And, you know, these these personal ads which kind of pick up your as you walk along the street, they sort of pick up your signature and direct personal ads at you.
We've all been freaked out by what Instagram can do to you when it can really predict your desires in quite extraordinary ways.
So that sort of sense of that artificial intelligence has obviously has been a kind of key idea.
And people are are we on the edge of what's called the technological singularity, which is where machines become conscious.
Even just a couple of months ago, someone in Google said, wait a minute, I think this I think my computer's just got just got sentient.
And he was probably moved from his job. But actually, that idea of we're right on the edge of this kind of development is is is partly due to science fiction,
partly due to science fiction being so fluid now with advanced technology companies, startup companies, you know, tech kind of stuff.
We all look to Elon Musk, who's doing research into telepathy effectively and also extended life research, which is massive in the Silicon Valley.
You know, will Walt Disney's head that's been frozen allegedly be reanimated?
His family repeatedly deny that his head is frozen, by the way.
And, you know, that sort of culture of can we escape the bounds of the human itself? It feels very kind of vibrant.
And that's for me why science fiction is so vital now is there's a sense of all the technology is accelerating.
We're in the middle of a revolution, a digital revolution. We don't quite know where it's going.
We can do these extraordinary things now with gene editing.
Do we have enough kind of moral, ethical capacities to control that?
And it's science fiction that imagines both good versions and bad versions of what might come out of that.
And understanding the history of science fiction and how it's shaped our understanding of reality in the past can help us make sense of where we might be going in the future.
Yeah, definitely. I mean, and I think that's both, you know, both hard in the sense of technology and science,
but also soft in the sense of what are the political consequences of this kind of thing?
So, you know, The Handmaid's Tale by Margaret Atwood, written as an attack on conservative Reagan world in the 1980s,
suddenly gets this major new boost, not just from shifting media, so becoming a TV streamed series,
but also because of a political context in which abortion is suddenly shifted in the States and all of the protests pick up on the imaginary of Handmaid's Tale.

And isn't it freaky that a certain version of it has started to emerge, suggests the power of the imagination to project kind of forward and to warn,
but also to embrace and celebrate as well as question or just say it's completely unpredictable what's going to happen.
